newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West spot power weakens, supplies abundant.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West spot power weakens, supplies abundant.

text.p: Spot power prices in the western U.S. slipped amid abundant offers from marketers and expected warmer weather next week, trade sources said Friday.
The combination of Monday with Tuesday deals due to the Presidents Day holiday also put downward pressure on melded prices, they said.
"Loads are coming off and there is a holiday on Monday so prices are a bit softer," said one trader.
Another trader noted that most of the offers were from power marketers, with utilities relatively reluctant sellers at lower prices.
"They (utilities) have the option of selling in the real-time market," he added.
The Pacific Northwest was expected to see temperatures 4 to 8 degrees F above average through Sunday, and near normal through early next week.
The Southwest was expected to see temperatures 3 to 6 degrees above normal through Monday, and near normal early next week.
Firm, peak electricity at the California-Oregon border (COB) for Monday-Tuesday was quoted at $10.50-$11.50 a megawatt hour (MWh), compared with $12.00-12.75 for Friday.
Firm, off-peak COB deliveries for Monday-Tuesday were unchanged at $7.50-8.00.
Firm, peak electricity at Mid-Columbia (Mid-C) for Monday-Tuesday was quoted at $10.00-11.00, compared with $10.50-11.50 for Friday.
Off-peak Mid-C for day-ahead delivery was quoted at $5.50-6.50.
Firm, peak Palo Verde (PV) electricity was quoted at $13.00-14.00, while off-peak deliveries were at $7.00-8.00.
Next-day firm, peak power at Four Corners was quoted at $14.00-15.00, while off-peak remained at $7.00-9.00.
